headline.print_headline: Genetic Tests Offer Promise, but Raise Questions, Too
headline.main: Genetic Tests Offer Promise, but Raise Questions, Too

docs.lead_paragraph: As commercial labs make strides, what about patient protections?
docs.snippet: As commercial labs make strides, what about patient protections?

headline.main: Genetic Tests Offer Promise, but Raise Questions, Too

docs.abstract: Denise Caruso column on molecular diagnostic tests, which can give doctors more detailed information about patients, help them make more accurate diagnoses and more readily detect serious autoimmune disorders and help medical researchers; questions are being raised because there is no government requirement that tests offered by commercial labs must relate to particular disease or risk of disease in order to be sold to public; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A GROWING industry is hoping to spin gold from DNA's double helixes by using ultrasensitive genetic tests to personalize medical treatment for cancer, lupus and other diseases. These molecular diagnostic tests can give doctors more detailed information than ever about their patients. Genetic information can help them decide whether their lymphoma patients would respond better to surgery, chemotherapy or radiation treatment; make more accurate diagnoses of abnormal cells or tissues; and more readily detect serious autoimmune disorders.

headline.print_headline: Regional Variation Seen in Heart Disease Rate
headline.main: Regional Variation Seen in Heart Disease Rate

docs.lead_paragraph: West Virginia and Kentucky, states known for high levels of obesity, diabetes and smoking, have the highest proportion of people with heart disease, officials said.
docs.snippet: West Virginia and Kentucky, states known for high levels of obesity, diabetes and smoking, have the highest proportion of people with heart disease, officials said.

headline.main: Regional Variation Seen in Heart Disease Rate

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that West Virginia and Kentucky have highest proportion of people with heart disease; states in Southeast and Southwest lead in heart disease, and Colorado and District of Columbia have lowest percentages; regional differences are believed to stem from rates of obesity, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes and smoking and other known factors for heart disease, according to lead author (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: West Virginia and Kentucky, states known for high levels of obesity, diabetes and smoking, have the highest proportion of people with heart disease in the nation, health officials said Thursday. The findings, from the first study to look at the prevalence of heart disease state by state, showed that states in the Southeast and Southwest led in heart disease. Colorado and the District of Columbia had the lowest percentages.
